fmt::Son< stacksize > Class Template Reference

Documentation

template<int stacksize>
class fmt::Son< stacksize >

The SON (Stratify Object Notation) is an important class to be familiar with. It is closely related to JSON (and very closely related to BSON). It allows you to store, access, and modify data in the same way but is designed for use on resource constrained systems.

Important things to note:

  • Key names are limited to 7 characters (longer names are truncated)
  • The stacksize template value is the depth limit when creating files
  • You can only append to files that are left with an open ended array
  • You can't modify the length of strings or data objects within a file
  • You must create root ("") as the first object or array

Creation example:

#include <sapi/fmt.hpp>
int main(int argc, char * argv[]){
Son son<4>; //depth is limited to 4
//tabs are added to help visualize the parallel to JSON
son.create("/home/settings.son");
son.open_obj("");
son.write("name", "Stratify"); //create a string
son.write("date", "today"); //create another string
son.write("value", (u32)100); //write a number);
son.open_obj("time"); //create a new object
son.write("hour", 12); //add some values
son.write("min", 00);
son.write("sec", 59);
son.close_obj(); //close 'time'
son.close_obj(); //close root ""
son.close();
char buffer[32];
u32 value;
son.open("/home/settings.son"); //opens read-only
son.read_str("name", buffer, 32);
//buffer holds "Stratify"
value = son.read_unum("hour");
son.read_str("sec", buffer, 32);
//buffer holds "59"
son.to_json("/home.settings.json");
son.close();
}

The settings.json files looks like: 

{
    "name": "Stratify",
    "date": "today",
    "value": "100",
    "stuff": {
        "hour": "12",
        "min": "0",
        "sec": "59"
     }
}

son_size_t  size 
)
inline

Edits a data value.

Parameters
accessThe access code for the value
dataA pointer to the source data
sizeThe number of bytes to edit
Returns
Zero on success

If size exceeds the size of the orginal data object, the new data will be truncated to that size.

template<int stacksize>
int fmt::Son< stacksize >::get_error ( )
inline

Gets the current error value. The current error value is returned. This method will clear the error value such that if it is called twice it will return the error then it will return SON_ERR_NONE.

Returns
The error value

Reads the specified key as data. Regardless of the storage type, the key will be returned as binary data.

template<int stacksize>
float fmt::Son< stacksize >::read_float ( const char *  access)
inline

Reads the specified key as a number (float). If the original key was not written as a s32, it will be converted to one. A string of "100" will be converted to (float)100. Objects that cannot be converted will return 0.

Parameters
accessKey parameters
Returns
The number
template<int stacksize>
s32 fmt::Son< stacksize >::read_num ( const char *  access)
inline

Reads the specified key as a number (s32). If the original key was not written as a s32, it will be converted to one. A string of "100" will be converted to (s32)100. Objects that cannot be converted will return 0.

Parameters
accessKey parameters
Returns
The number
template<int stacksize>
int fmt::Son< stacksize >::read_str ( const char *  access,
char *  str,
son_size_t  capacity 
)
inline

Reads the specified key as a string. If the original key was not written as a string, it will be converted to a string. For example, a (u32)100 will be converted to "100". A data object will be converted to base64 encoding.

Parameters
accessKey parameters
strPointer to the destination data
capacitySize of str buffer
Returns
The number of bytes actually read
template<int stacksize>
int fmt::Son< stacksize >::read_str ( const char *  access,

)
inline

Reads the specified key as a string. If the original key was not written as a string, it will be converted to a string. For example, a (u32)100 will be converted to "100". A data object will be converted to base64 encoding.

Parameters

strvar::String reference
Returns
The number of bytes actually read
template<int stacksize>
u32 fmt::Son< stacksize >::read_unum ( const char *  access)
inline

Reads the specified key as a number (u32). If the original key was not written as a s32, it will be converted to one. A string of "100" will be converted to (u32)100. Objects that cannot be converted will return 0.

Parameters
accessKey parameters
Returns
The number

Writes a key/data pair to the file. The data is stored in the file in binary format

Returns

template<int stacksize>
int fmt::Son< stacksize >::write_open_data ( const void *  v,
son_size_t  size 
)
inline

Adds data to an open key. This is used with open_data() and close_data(). These methods are useful for writing data to the file when the amount of data to be written is unknown when writing begins.

#include <sapi/Var.hpp>
Son son<4>;
son.create("/home/data.son");
son.open_data("datakey");
son.write_open_data(buffer, 32);
son.close_data();
Parameters
keyThe value key
vA pointer to the data to be written
sizeThe number of bytes to write
Returns
Number of bytes stored (4) if successful
